items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Lake Levels are beginning to fall, however further rain throughout today 26/11/2022, is expected to cause the lake and river levels to rise again. Flooding may affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

As a result of high spring tides, flooding is possible along the Coast at North Morecambe Bay between 12:00 PM and 13:00 PM on 26/11/2022. Flooding is possible one hour either side of this time. Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. The tide overnight tonight Saturday 26/11/2022 into Sunday is not forecast to reach flood alert thresholds. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads in the area. This message will be updated by 17:30 PM on 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This alert is no longer in force due to improving weather conditions.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This alert is no longer in force due to improving weather conditions.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.79mAOD at 16:00 on 26/11/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking today. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 108 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:00 on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This flood alert has been issued due to high tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast today, Saturday 26/11/2022, between 08:00 PM and 09:30 PM. Areas most at risk include the area around Bridlington lifeboat station and South Pier at Bridlington. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 06:00 PM on 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: This flood alert has now been removed. We will continue to monitor the local water levels and weather closely and reissue the alert if necessary.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message: The Saturday evening tide at 07:15 PM is forecast to be higher than normal due to the unsettled stormy weather and may cause spray overtopping of the defences.  Heavy rain and force 7 westerly winds are also forecast.  Flooding is possible at Castletown, Weymouth, Preston Beach, Swanage Bay, Studland Bay, Sandbanks, Poole Harbour, Bournemouth Beach, Hengistbury Head and Christchurch Harbour between 06:45 PM and 08:00 PM on 26/11/2022.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous.  This message will be updated by 13:00 noon on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

As a result of bad weather this evening, large waves are forecast to overtop sea defences with sea spray.  The large waves and the tidal surge will help to increase the water levels and the  forecast high water is between 08:00 PM and 09:00 PM on the 26th November with a total water level of 5.57mAOD at West Bay and a Force 7 westerley wind.  All times are local and refer to the high water times at West Bay.  mAOD is height above average sea level and for more detail please refer to your local tide tables.  Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect Lyme Regis, Charmouth, Seatown, West Bay, Bothenhampton, Burton Freshwater, Burton Bradstock, Cogdean Beach, Chesil Beach, West Fleet, East Fleet and Chiswell.   Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.  We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 13:00 on Sunday 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Upper River Wey, especially in the Passfield Mill areas. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. Further rainfall is forecast today. Levels have stabilised on the Wey but will remain high over the coming days and are sensitive to further rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this afternoon, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message: River levels remain high but steady at the Milford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby, the Mountsorrel to Sileby road, the access road to Sileby Mill, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 18:00 today, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Hints river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday 24/11/22. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today 25/11/22. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook. Further showers is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout today and into this evening 25/11/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   
  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. However, there is further rainfall forecast later on Saturday, 26/11/22, and into Sunday, 27/11/22, therefore the river levels are likely to rise again in response to this rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Sunday, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne, especially in the Free Prae Road area. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. Levels are currently falling on the Chertsey Bourne but may rise and come out of banks again due to additional rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast for today.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but generally steady at the Willington and Shardlow river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to remain high for the next couple of days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 20:00 on 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Saturday evening's tide is forecast to be higher than normal and could reach 2.47m due to unsettled weather.  Heavy rain and force 7 westerly winds are also forecast.  Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit. Flooding is possible at West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit between 08:00 PM and 09:00 PM on 26/11/2022. Weather conditions are expected to produce large offshore waves. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. This message will be updated by 13:00 noon on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding has now reduced, and wind and wave conditions have calmed.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels remain high at the Torksey and Gainsborough river gauges as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road, Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith, TW Logistics, Gainsborough Railway Bridge and Beckingham Marshes. We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 27/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 21:00, 26/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Wedderburn Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leadon. Locations that may be affected include Ledbury, Much Marcle, Staunton and Tibberton. Water may be out of bank at Upleadon Court. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are beginning to fall at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks Llanymynech peaked at 3.58m on 25/11/22.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast to day. We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 4pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is higher than normal, but is currently slowly falling. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads and possibly the gardens of properties near Mock Bridge on Friday. Friday should stay mostly dry. River levels will continue to fall through Friday and Saturday. However, a lot of rain (50mm) is forecast from 20:00 Saturday evening 26/11/2022. The River Adur will rise and could cause property flooding at Mock Bridge. River levels could rise to a similar height of the peak Thursday 17 November 2022. River levels are unlikely to return nearer to normal until the middle of next week. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impacts of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 26/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is higher than normal, but following the dry weather yesterday (25/11/22), it continues to slowly fall. Today, residual flood impacts affecting roads, cycle tracks and footpaths is expected. At Sandown, the river is now low enough to allow ditches around Fort Holiday Park to drain. However, by early afternoon (26/11/22) and into Sunday (27/11/22) further heavy rain (20-40mm) is forecast. The river will rise quickly in response to any rain and it will cause additional flooding impacts to land, gardens and roads. Should 40mm of rain affect the river, then property flooding may occur at Alverstone and Langbridge. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding can operate. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday 27/11/2022, or sooner if we think property flooding will occur.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall on Thursday 24 November. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding, however further heavy rainfall is forecast this evening, Saturday 26 November, and tomorrow, Sunday 27 November where river levels will rise again.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 9pm Saturday 26 November 2022 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible on the afternoon and evening of Saturday 26th November. Over the last week we have seen heavy rainfall and the ground is now very wet. Heavy rainfall is forecast to cross the area from midday, with prolonged rainfall forecast for this afternoon and into the evening. Rainfall of between 16-40mm is possible. Rivers are expected to respond and peak at around midnight tonight.  

Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast.   

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 8pm on Saturday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

The Western Rother is higher than normal between Midhurst and FIttleworth but is now slowly falling. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens near Fittleworth. Friday should stay mostly dry. River levels will continue to fall through Friday and Saturday. However, a lot of rain (50mm) is forecast from 20:00 Saturday evening 26/11/2022. River levels will rise in all communities and could cause property flooding along the length of the Western Rother. River levels could possibly rise higher than the peaks of last week. River levels are unlikely to return nearer to normal until next week. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impacts of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 26/11/2022.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 26/11/2022 may cause flooding, as the condition of the shingle beach has been impacted by Thursday's high energy waves. Winds are strong South Westerly Force 5. The weather increases tide table values by 0.12 m. The total forecast tide is 6.06 metres Chart Datum (3.01 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minor flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Sunday's early morning tide is forecast to be very similar, but with larger waves. Minor flood impacts are expected until Monday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest.  Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 17:00 on 26/11/2022.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high, following twice the monthly average rainfall in November, but is now slowly falling. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Some roads, including Shripney Lane may be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. In Barnham, only minimal impacts are currently expected, with river levels comparatively lower. Friday should stay mostly dry. River levels will continue to fall through Saturday. However a lot of rain (50mm) is forecast from 20:00 Saturday evening 26/11/2022. River levels will rise on both the Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes. Possibly even higher than the peak of last week. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impacts of flooding. We continue to monitor the situation and routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 20:00 26/11/2022.

items.message:
The river level on the Washford River at Beggearn Huish remains high and above the flood alert level but is currently stable. All other rivers are currently below levels of concern. A mostly dry day is forecast for today, Friday 25/11/22, but further wet weather is forecast to return during Saturday afternoon and into Sunday with the possibility of flooding of low-lying land and roads. The flooding of properties is not forecast at this time. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday, 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast today.  We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 4pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding is possible on the afternoon and evening of Saturday 26th November. Over the last week we have seen heavy rainfall and the ground is now very wet. Heavy rainfall is forecast to cross the area from midday, with prolonged rainfall forecast for this afternoon and into the evening. Rainfall of between 16-40mm is possible. Rivers are expected to respond and peak at around midnight tonight.  

Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast.   

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 8pm on Saturday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Great Somerford river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge.   
  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. However, there is further rainfall forecast later on Saturday, 26/11/22, and into Sunday, 27/11/22, therefore the river levels are likely to rise again in response to this rainfall
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Sunday, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.54 m and is currently falling by 5 mm per hour. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.28 m and is currently stable. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load above 7.86 m and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m. Property flooding is not expected at this time. Pumping will take place at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station when river levels allow.
A mostly dry day is forecast for today, Friday 25/11/22, but further wet weather is forecast to return during Saturday afternoon and into Sunday with the possibility of flooding of low-lying land and roads.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday, 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on the afternoon and evening of Saturday 26th November. Over the last week we have seen heavy rainfall and the ground is now very wet. Heavy rainfall is forecast to cross the area from midday, with prolonged rainfall forecast for this afternoon and into the evening. Rainfall of between 16-40mm is possible. Rivers are expected to respond and peak at around midnight tonight.  

Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast.   

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 8pm on Saturday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are continuing to fall at the Covington Brook river gauge this morning but remain high downstream following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 26/11/22. Flooding is affecting the River Kym and River Til from Yelden and Upper Dean to Hail Weston. 
Further rainfall is forecast today, 26/11/22 and river levels may rise again in response to this. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated this afternoon 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are continuing to fall at the Riseley river gauge this morning but remain high downstream following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 26/11/22. Flooding is affecting Riseley Brook from Riseley to Pertenhall. 
Further rainfall is forecast today, 26/11/22 and river levels may rise again in response to this. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated this afternoon 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.54m and is currently falling by 15mm per hour. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m.
The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.99m and is rising by 10mm per hour. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30m. Flooding of properties is not forecast and pumping will take place at Currymoor as soon as river levels allow. 
A mostly dry day is forecast for today, Friday 25/11/22, but further wet weather is forecast to return during Saturday afternoon and into Sunday with the possibility of flooding of low-lying land and roads.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday, 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded.

Continued bands of heavy rain have fallen onto saturated ground in the Upper River Witham catchment.  River levels remain high. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout Saturday 26th November with further rain forecast overnight Saturday into Sunday. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Sunday 27th November or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are high but are beginning to fall at the Brentingby Dam and Frisby river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding of farm land and low lying roads in the Melton and Asfordby areas, including Station Lane Ashfordly including low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 18:00 today, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels remain high on the River Ouse in response to recent heavy rainfall. Levels in York will remain high today, Saturday, 26/11/2022. Flooding of low-lying land is expected. Areas most at risk include riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Further rainfall is expected today, Saturday 26/11/2022, and we expect levels to remain high. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts. This message will be updated by 4pm on 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 36 hours.  We continue to monitor the situation. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels continue to remain high on the Upper River Derwent due to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected in locations near the River Derwent, particularly low-lying land upstream of Malton today, Saturday, 26/11/2022. Further rainfall is expected today, Saturday 26/11/2022, and river levels are expected to remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 4pm on 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels continue to remain high on the Lower River Derwent due to recent rainfall. Flooding remains possible in locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Buttercrambe, Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington. Further rainfall is expected today, Saturday 26/11/2022 and river levels are expected to remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 4pm on 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been rising on the middle to lower part of the River Cherwell as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue especially in the areas around Thrupp. We are expecting rain this afternoon (Saturday) and into Sunday. We expect river levels to continue very slowly rising for the next 12 - 24 hours from Thrupp down to Oxford.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
This message will be updated on Sunday, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast today.  We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 4pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Croxall river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/12/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast in the next 48 hours.  
Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Glaze catchment including Leigh and East Wigan
items.message:
River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the River Glaze.
Further rain throughout the afternoon is expected to cause the river level to rise this afternoon peaking at 04:15 PM on 26/11/2022.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around Moss, Hey, Bedford and Borsdane Brooks and their tributaries.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the evening.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updatedas the situation changes.

River levels are beginning to fall at the Cappenham river gauge this morning but remain high downstream following recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 26/11/22.  Flooding is affecting River Tove from Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook. 
Further rainfall is forecast today, 26/11/22 and river levels may rise again in response to this. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated this afternoon 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Great Ouse in Northamptonshire, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, West Northamptonshire

items.message:
River levels are continuing to fall at the Brackley river gauge this morning but remain high downstream following recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 26/11/22. Flooding is affecting River Great Ouse from Brackley to Haversham, including Padbury Brook.   
 
Further rainfall is forecast today, 26/11/22 and river levels may rise again in response to this. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated this afternoon 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast in the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall is forecast tonight Saturday 26/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Recent heavy bands of rain have caused river levels to rise on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the river will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding at North Bank Road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media.

River levels have risen at the Gloucester river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore and low lying land at Quedgeley / Stonebench. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. Predicted peaks: Mythe 3.6m to 3.8m at 00:15 on Sunday morning, 27/11/22. Upper Pound 3.6m to 3.8m at 00:15 on Sunday morning, 27/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 5pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: High tides are due today Saturday 26/11/22. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.7m to 3.9m at 10:30 this morning, 3.7m to 3.9m at 23:15 this evening Saturday 26/11/22. Gloucester 3.4m to 3.6m at 10:15 this morning, 3.4m to 3.6m at 23:00 this evening Saturday 26/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and the Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may also be affecting the racecourse and the Worcester County cricket ground. Predicted peaks:- Kempsey Yacht Club 5.3m to 5.6m overnight Sunday into Monday morning, 28/11/22. Diglis 3.2m to 3.5m overnight Sunday into Monday morning, 28/11/22. Worcester 3.5m to 3.8m overnight Sunday into Monday morning, 28/11/22. Saxons Lode 4.1m to 4.3m overnight Sunday into Monday morning, 28/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Bredon river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation scheme is now operational. Predicted peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 5.3m to 5.6m overnight Sunday into Monday morning, 28/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 5pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 12:36 on 26/11/2022 may cause flooding, as high tides on Thursday (24/11/2022) removed material from the beach which protects South Hayling. Winds are strong Southerly Force 5. The weather increases tide table values by 0.13 m. The total forecast tide is 5.11 metres Chart Datum (2.38 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Property flooding is not expected. At Eastoke Corner, the beach crest remains very narrow. Overtopping into the promenade is possible in this location. At South Hayling, waves could remove shingle again. If this happens, it could cause overtopping into beach front gardens at Southwood Road, Bembridge Drive, Meath Close and The Strand. At 01:06 on Sunday morning (27/11/2022) the tide and flood impacts will be similar. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. We are liaising with the local authority and their response teams, over the condition of the beach at South Hayling. Avoid South Hayling seafront at high tide. Shingle and debris can be thrown by strong winds. We will update this message by 18:00 on 26/11/2022.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been falling on the River Evenlode, but are still high on the River Glyme particularly around Woodstock. This is as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week. Water may remain on roads and farmland however further flooding is not expected for the next 24 hours. We are expecting rain this afternoon (Saturday) and into Sunday. We expect river levels to remain high on the river Glyme over the next few days.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Sunday, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but starting to fall slowly at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks Crew Green peaked at 5.5m yesterday morning, Montford peaked at 4.6m  this morning, Welshbridge 2.3m to 2.5m Saturday morning, Buildwas 3.5m to 3.7m Saturday overnight, Bridgnorth 2.8m to 3.0m Sunday.   
We expect river levels to remain high until 27/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 4pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Hayling and South Eastoke seafront
items.message: The lunchtime tide today at Portsmouth came in as forecast at 5.06 metres Chart Datum (2.33 mAOD). Impacts were not as severe as expected. Saturdays very early morning tide at 00:18 on the 26/11/2022 is elevated but not expected to be as high. Saturdays lunchtime tide at 12:30 on the 26/11/2022 is forecast at 5.12 metres Chart Datum (2.39 mAOD). These may cause minor impact flooding to coastal roads and car parks. A Flood Alert will remain in force to describe the impacts of these tides. We continue to monitor the forecast, and are liaising with the local authority and their response teams over the condition of the beach at South Hayling. The excavator has been on site re-forming the beach crest. At high tide, waves and water may be higher up the beach than normal. Avoid South Hayling seafront at high tide. Shingle and debris can be thrown by strong winds and large waves.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels are still high on the Bear Brook in Western Turnville. Flooding of areas next to the river is still possible but not expected. We will continue to monitor the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Sandhurst river gauge.  Tides will be at their highest at 10:15 this morning and 23:00 this evening, Saturday 26/11/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect Coal Wharf and Riverside, Maisemore and Sandhurst Lane. Base Lane, Sandhurst may also flood. A417 Over to Maisemore maybe closed due to flooding. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.7m to 3.9m at 10:30 this morning, 3.7m to 3.9m at 23:15 this evening Saturday 26/11/22. Gloucester 3.4m to 3.6m at 10:15 this morning, 3.4m to 3.6m at 23:00 this evening Saturday 26/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 5pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been rising on the River Ray as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week especially around Islip. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue around Islip. We are expecting rain this afternoon (Saturday) and into Sunday. We expect river levels to continue very slowly rising for the next 12 - 24 hours.
We are  monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Sunday, or as the situation changes.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 26/11/2022 may cause flooding, as the condition of the shingle beach has been impacted by Thursday's high energy waves. Winds are strong South Westerly Force 5. The weather increases tide table values by 0.12 m. The total forecast tide is 6.06 metres Chart Datum (3.01 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minor flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Sunday's early morning tide is forecast to be very similar, but with larger waves. Minor flood impacts are expected until Monday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest. As a precaution, please take action to protect property on Climping Street at least 2 hours before high tide. We will update this message by 17:00 on 26/11/2022.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels are remaining high on the River Dee. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Townfield Lane is cut off. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday 26/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury. Predicted peaks: Mythe 3.6m to 3.8m at 00:15 on Sunday morning, 27/11/22. Upper Pound 3.6m to 3.8m at 00:15 on Sunday morning, 27/11/22.    
Further rainfall is forecast tonight. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and closing flood gates.  
Please call 999 if in immediate danger. 
This message will be updated by 5pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today Saturday 26/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge.   
Further rainfall is forecast overnight tonight Saturday 26/11/2022.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 5pm on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on the afternoon and evening of Saturday 26th November. Over the last week we have seen heavy rainfall and the ground is now very wet. Heavy rainfall is forecast to cross the area from midday, with prolonged rainfall forecast for this afternoon and into the evening. Rainfall of between 16-40mm is possible. Rivers are expected to respond and peak at around midnight tonight.  

Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast.   

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 8pm on Saturday evening or earlier if the situation changes.
